description.narrative: Results: Improved governance for effective implementation of the National Rural Development Strategy, improved rural economic diversification, employment and services; Improved environment, sustainable management of natural resources and climate action.

participating-org.narrative: Min. Env. Prot. & Agri. of GEO

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: Impact: 1. Increased average monthly incomes per household in rural areas 1. Decreased unemployment rate (disaggregated by sex, rural/urban) Outcome: 1. More relevant RDS, RDAP and more integrated governance mechanisms for rural development involving national, regional and municipal levels adopted and implemented with support from the project 2. Increased rural employment in non-agriculture sector as part of total employment (disaggregated by sex) Output: 1.1 Objectively measurable indicators defined and regularly monitored under each priority/objective of the RDAP using evidence-based data collection and analysis under a functional M&E system (National, Ajara) 1.2 Annual reviews of RDAP completed on the basis of reliable information and evidence-based data on progress and achievements (National, Ajara) 2.1 Increased number of non-agricultural jobs created in targeted rural areas with support from the project, disaggregated by sex/age 2.2 Increased average monthly income of households in targeted rural areas supported by the project, disaggregated by sex/age 3.1 Increased number of hectares of forest and protected areas in targeted rural areas where sustainable and climate-resilient management practices have been introduced with support from the project 2.2 Increase number of households in targeted rural areas receiving direct incentives to improve energy efficiency and other climate-related benefits with support from the project

comment.narrative: 1. impact -Improved employment and living conditions of the rural population in Georgia as a result of better quality and quantity of available rural services Impact - 1. 809 GEL (2017); 2. Average 13.9% (12.7% female/15.0% male; 22.8% urban/5.1% rural) (2016) Outcome - 1. Adopted 2 RDS (National, Ajara); 2. adopted and implemented 2 RDAP (National and Ajara); implemented 3 LDS (2016); 26.6% of rural people employed in non-agriculture sector nationwide; (2016) Output - 1.1. No indicators defined at the level of priorities/objectives; no M&E system in place (National, Ajara) (2016) 1.2 No annual reviews of RDAP available (National, Ajara) (2016) 2.1 Zero (2017) 2.2 Kakheti – GEL 719; Kvemo Kartli – GEL882; Samtskhe-Javakheti - GEL843; Ajara – GEL922; Mtskheta Mtianeti – GEL657 (2017) 3.1 Zero (2017) 3.2 Zero (2017)

1.1 N/A 1.2 N/A 2.1 6 Municipal Assessment Reports developed 2.2 Target for Average Monthly Income of households defined 3.1 Support measures for target forests Management Plans planned and agreed 3.2 Targeted interventions on protection/sustainable management of natural resources, climate change, disaster risk management and use renewable and alternative sources of energy designed and agreed with stakeholders

1.1 Activities for the particular output will start in 2019
1.2 Activities for the particular output will start in 2019
2.1 6 Municipal Assessment Reports developed - Rural Non-Farm Economy Needs Survey has been completed. It was comprised of two sub-surveys: populations and non-farm business surveys. The aim of surveys was to reveal and analyze the main challenges and opportunities of economic diversification in target municipalities. To this end, quantitative surveys through face-to-face interviews and structured questionnaires were carried in 6 target municipalities: Akhalkalaki, Borjomi, Dedoplistskaro, Kazbegi, Lagodekhi and Tetritskaro. In populations survey totally 3477 interviews were conducted and in business survey 580 interviews. Currently, the data form quantitative survey is analyzed and will be completed by the beginning of the January 2019.
In parallel with quantitative survey, Municipal Assessment Reports (MARs) have been conducted. Assessments were conducted through qualitative means: desk research, secondary data analysis, observations, in-depth interviews, etc. Currently the Municipal Assessment Reports for each target municipalities are being finalized and will incorporate the findings of the quantitative Rural Non-Farm Economy Needs survey. The results of Municipal Assessment Reports (MARs) will inform the decisions about planned direct support mechanisms for rural economic diversification and environmental protection and sustainable management of natural resources. The results of both surveys will be communicated with the Ministry of Environmental Protection and Agriculture of Georgia in order to agree on various issues of Rural Development in targeted municipalities, mainly direct support mechanism.
2.2 Target for Average Monthly Income of households defined - target is partially completed. Definition of target for average monthly income of households is directly linked with finalization of Municipal Assessment Report, which will happen in the first quarter of 2019.
3.1 Support measures for target forests Management Plans planned and agreed - A standard letter of agreement between the united nations development programme and National Forest Agency of Georgia to carry out activities when UNDP provides support services to the project “Improving Rural Development in Georgia” developed and agreed with the ministry and agency and will be signed in the first quarter of 2019.
3.2 Targeted interventions on protection/sustainable management of natural resources, climate change, disaster risk management and use renewable and alternative sources of energy designed and agreed with stakeholders - An initial list of interventions designed and discussed with stakeholders for further feedback and comments. It is planned to have a final, agreed list of interventions in the first quarter of 2019.

1.1/1.2 - Common (IACC) RDS Monitoring Framework and M&E system established - E-M&E system enhanced for better data management and analysis for compiling analytical reports - MEPA has improved EU-style structures and processes - The staff has the capacities to implement effective RD governance - MEPA initiates decisions explicitly based on M&E evidenced (MS and reporting under dimension M&E) - Improved inter-agency coordination on RD planning and implementation - Institutional citizen engagement in local/rural decision-making and implementation processes improved - Informal horizontal exchange network within private, public, and civil sector representatives – a resilient network for information sharing and knowledge transfer mechanisms created - Local self-government decisions are stimulated on achieving sustainable improvements of internal organizational and citizen engagement practices in the mid-term policy making and budgeting processes. - Integrated RD policy and policy action planning launched - Approval of the 3-year Action Plan for RDA Institutional Reform; - Amendment in the statute of IACC and establishment of the Civic Committee. - IACC partners and Municipalities started coordinating their actions at the local level - A common e-M&E system is a functional and respective staff equipped with relevant capacities.
2.1/2.2 - Individual businesses supported through targeted interventions - Disadvantaged rural residents included in support - Systemic support to target municipalities - Specific priorities and delivery mechanisms to support COVID-19 Crisis and post-crisis period economic diversification measures identified in the target municipalities
3.1 - Forests inspection in two target municipalities ongoing - Ecotourism potential in Ajara enhanced
3.2 - First EE/RE technologies sold under a scheme for the development of rural markets for EE/RE - Innovative EE/RE solutions introduced - Awareness created on EE/RE

1.1/1.2 • Data collection tool, reporting, and GIS functions are incorporated into an e-M&E system of National Rural Development Strategy and Action Plans. • The Annual Report of the National RDAP for 2019 completed, the National RDAP Annual Report for 2019 approved by IACC and uploaded on the MEPA’s website - https://mepa.gov.ge/Ge/Reports • National RDAP for 2020 are updated; National one adopted by the GoG). • Impact level Indicators of the RDSG 2017-2020 adopted by IACC. • Semi-annual progress report of the RDAP for 2020 aggregated and elaborated • Gender and Geographically disaggregated data introduced for the RDAP semi-annual reporting through GIS in an e-M&E system on National level. • A RDAP Impact level Indicators’ description developed. • Package of recommendations on changes to organizational capabilities and behavior based on specific and unambiguous governance requirements (EC regulations, EU MS practice, and adapted to the Georgian public administration) and good practice presented to MEPA. • Agreement with ARDA on drafting the Multi-year action plan for the implementation of the recommendation package on Paying Agency. • MEPA endorsed recommendations on organizational changes and core business processes in line with EU RD Managing Authority requirements. • MEPA endorsed recommendations on institutional reform of the Rural Development Agency towards setting up an EU-type Paying Agency. • MEPA endorsed recommendations on setting up a Civic Committee in line with the Monitoring Committees operating in each EU Member State. • The national rural network to become part of MEPA’s operational environment for learning from experience, reflection, and improvement of RD policy and org. performance and envisioning and communicating a better future with stakeholders and the wider public. • MEPA/MRDI agreed to map and document participatory local budgeting and community engagement. • IACC supports the effective functioning of the Civic Committee. • IACC approved the impact indicators for RDSG 2017-2020; completed the Annual Report for the RDAP for 2019 and updated the RDAP for 2020. • Proposed changes in MEPA and IACC’s “business model” to remain agile and relevant to the needs of partners and stakeholders, taking seriously their perceptions and concerns and leading change by actively engaging them - package of recommendations on setting up a Civic Committee in line with the Monitoring Committees operating in each EU Member State submitted to MEPA. • UNDP/IRDG elaborated on a concept of the IACC integrated and synergetic actions. • Creation of Municipal Working Groups under IACC agreed with MEPA, IACC, and local authorities and LAGs in 6 target municipalities. • IACC and RDC agreed to provide disaggregated data of Gender and Geography to measure the performance of RDAPs for 2020. • 6 target municipalities and IACC Integrated coordination mechanism established. • IACC and RDC working group members provided disaggregated (gender and geographical) monitoring data for the 2020 RDAP/ARDAP semi-annual report through GIS tool in e-M&E Systems on the National and Ajara levels. • IACC/MEPA met with Dedoplistskaro, Lagodekhi, Aragvi, Akhmeta, Mestia, Tskaltubo and Tsalka Local Action Groups.
2.1/2.2 • Scope of work for various interventions (introduction of the concept of Smart Villages) adjusted to the COVID-19 impact developed • Borjomi Municipality Tourism Master Plan developed. • Matching grants program for rural non-farm businesses started. • Borjomi Tourism Master Plan approved by the local council • Hackathon on the topics of COVID-19 responses for rural tourism development and employment support completed. • 6 Smart Villages projects selected from Akhalkalaki 1, Dedoplistskaro 1, Kazbegi 1, Tetritskaro 2, Keda 1 in response and building resilience to COVID–19 pandemic”. • Growth poles identified for Lagodekhi Municipality. • Interventions for improving rural digitalization elaborated. • 25 proven, innovative, distinctively rural business models per target municipality identified. • Recommendations of the artisans’ products value chain analysis considered in the matching grant scheme – Rural Development Program. • Revised of Municipal Assessment Reports (MARs) of target municipalities identified rural support services in each municipality. • 13 grant contracts signed in the framework of the Rural Development Program.
3.1 • Initiated new LoA with NFA to prepare forest inventory of 2 Municipalities of Dedoplistskaro-Sighnaghi and Tetritskaro (total – 73,528 ha). • LoA with NFA to prepare forest inventory of 2 Municipalities of Dedoplistskaro-Sighnaghi and Tetritskaro (total – 73,528 ha) signed and activities initiated. • 16 taxators trained to conduct an inventory of the Dedoplistskaro-Sighnaghi and Tetritskaro municipalities’ forests.
3.2 • Innovative and suitable pro-poor technologies (solar water and solar air heaters) - identified and constructed. • Green Matching grant mechanism designed. • EE/RE demonstration sites in Keda, Khulo, Borjomi, and Kazbegi municipalities with participating households selected.

1.1 Major preconditions for an evidence-based RD policy making and implementation have been fulfilled (12/2019) 1.2 Institutional capacities for functional Rural Development Governance system defined and first actions taken (12/2019) 2.1/2.2 Grant delivery system is in place and first grant applications received (12/2019) 3.1 Forest management plan developed for one target municipality (12/2019) 3.2 Grant delivery system is in place and first grant applications received to implement targeted interventions on protection/sustainable management of natural resources, climate change, disaster risk reduction and use renewable and alternative sources of energy (12/2019).

1.1 • Electronic M&E systems elaborated, legitimized by the IACC. • Revisions to the National Rural Development Action Plan for 2018-2020 made and adopted by the Georgian Government. • Ajara AR web-based Monitoring and Evaluation system developed, functional and annual report data for 2018 entered. • Ajara AR Rural Development Action Plan annual report for 2018 prepared. • Relevant rural development data mapped according to their level of disaggregation. • LEADER AMAG – Shuakhevi was established and registered. • An Agriculture and Rural Development Strategy of Georgia (ARDSG) prepared and approved by MEPA along with the Rural Development Action Plan for 2021-2023 (annex #1). • A module of the Agriculture Development Strategy of Georgia (ADSG) and the Agriculture Development Action Plan (ADAP) for 2019-2020, added to the web-based M&E System, is functional. • An Agriculture and Rural Development Strategy of Georgia (ARDSG) prepared and approved by MEPA and GoG along with the Rural Development Action Plan for 2021-2023. • An Agriculture and Rural Development Strategy of Ajara AR (ARDSA) prepared and approved by MoA and Ajara AR Government. 2.1 • Essential features of RDP governance system in Georgia, institutional factors affecting the efficient and effective functioning of MEPA and challenges within the Ministry of Agriculture of Ajara AR defined. • Actions to support institutional strengthening of MEPA agreed with its leadership, including: (1) APMA reorganizing into an Agriculture and Rural Development paying Agency (ARDA); (2) HRM system switching from compliance to organizational and human capital development needs through streamlining HRM-related business processes; (3) Education and Information Center capacity building to better operate and fulfil its new mandate of a training center; (4) Organizational performance of the Department of Policy and Analysis and the Department of Agriculture, Food Safety and Rural Development through streamlined business processes and appropriate distribution of functions related to policy planning, implementation monitoring and evaluation process. • Priority focus directed at improving donor coordination mechanism increased; agreement reached with MEPA on introducing a new online information management platform to be administered by the International Relations Department. • MEPA demonstrated to undertake organizational reform to create a sustainable and EU-like governing structure for rural development aligned with the relevant EU provisions - a tangible meaning to the expression of ownership achieved. • Agriculture and Rural Development Agency (ARDA) was officially established on July 1, 2019 (annex #9). • With IRDG support, MEPA has been organizing discussions with civil society, private sector and rural community representatives on various RD topics, but to ensure systematic engagement MEPA has agreed to follow proposals developed by international and national experts on setting up a managing authority which foresees institutionalization of communication and engagement functions within responsible structural units. IACC role will be broadened, namely, agreement was reached to establish a “Public Discussion Platform” under IACC, allowing wider non-government stakeholders to be involved in rural development policy dialogue and monitoring of implementation • Capacity Development interventions for 8 municipalities identified; it will be primarily focused on strengthening local government participatory budgeting capacity and building (creating) capacity for citizen engagement and participation in planning and budgeting process for local/rural development. 2.1/2.2 • Priorities for clusters/growth poles agreed with all Local Action Groups (LAGs) and approved by Project Board. • Functional areas of municipalities identified to the extent possible. Agreement not required as they coincide to a large extent with municipal boundaries. • Delivery mechanism (“Rural Development Programme”), taking specific priorities into account, elaborated and agreed with partner (ARDA). • Innovative business model to improve the heating situation in rural areas through renewable energy and energy efficiency elaborated and approved by the Project Board. 3.1 • Letter of agreement (LoA) between UNDP and the National Forestry Agency (NFA) signed. • Inventory of forest (21 116 ha) in the Lagodekhi municipality completed successfully. 3.2 • Priorities assessed, defined and approved by Project Board: Thermal energy efficiency and renewable energy solutions, commercial use of Non-Timber-Forest-Products, forest waste to energy. • Delivery mechanism on energy efficiency and renewable energy for rural businesses elaborated and agreed with partner (within ARDA “Rural Development Programme”). • Delivery mechanism on energy efficiency and renewable energy for rural households elaborated and approved by Project Board. • Topics for awareness campaigns on climate change and use of renewable and alternative sources of energy identified.
